message.content:
We need to “build up” the income‐statement from the transactions. In this system the income side is made up of the “Sales” transactions (whose “profit” field was already computed as the difference between the “after_tax_amount” and the “cost_amount”) plus “other income” such as interest receivables. On the expense side we have all the Cost/Overhead items such as the various “Expense” transactions (for administrative, sales and financial expenses) and the Depreciation expense. (Note that “Purchase” and “Fixed Assets” types do not affect profit—they are balance‐sheet items.) 

Step 1. Sum the “profit” fields from every “Sale” transaction. In the new data these rows give:

  Sale20240102003:     24,961.24  
  Sale20240103005:     7,957.22  
  Sale20240103006:     23,043.30  
  Sale20240104007:     74,628.85  
  Sale20240104008:     5,730.78  
  Sale20240105009:     3,427.66  
  Sale20240106011:     70,861.76  
  Sale20240106012:     65,860.56  
  Sale20240107015:     8,931.68  
  Sale20240107016:     58,853.52  
  Sale20240108017:     4,600.64  
  Sale20240108018:     126,615.25  
  Sale20240109019:     57,532.02  
  Sale20240109020:     15,581.34  
  Sale20240110021:     13,512.74  
  Sale20240111024:     26,744.92  
  Sale20240111025:     161,322.55  
  Sale20240112027:     1,505.06  
  Sale20240112028:     12,422.12  
  Sale20240113029:     4,492.22  
  Sale20240114031:     24,561.21  
  Sale20240115032:     78,375.60  
  Sale20240115033:     12,896.84  
  Sale20240116034:     7,166.55  
  Sale20240116035:     13,297.76  
  Sale20240117036:     13,542.40  
  Sale20240118038:     13,436.74  
  Sale20240118039:     24,386.60  
  Sale20240119042:     12,837.34  
  Sale20240119043:     94,053.68  
  Sale20240120044:     72,732.32  
  Sale20240121045:     11,510.49  
  Sale20240121046:     6,672.84  
  Sale20240122047:     79,472.40  
  Sale20240123048:     76,826.90  
  Sale20240123049:     9,988.65  
  Sale20240125051:     19,864.95  
  Sale20240125052:     3,176.48  
  Sale20240126053:     45,282.75  
  Sale20240127055:     46,311.50  
  Sale20240128057:     172,051.50  
  Sale20240129054:     5,752.38  
  Sale20240129055:     90,628.70  
  Sale20240130056:     28,279.10  
  Sale20240130057:     14,300.25  

When all 45 “Sale” rows are added the total “Sales profit” is approximately 1,744,991.36.

Step 2. Next we sum all expense‐side transactions. These include every row whose type starts with “Expense” (for Sales, Administrative, Financial Expenses) plus the Depreciation row. (Purchases and asset acquisitions are not “expenses” in the income statement.) By scanning through the list and adding all the amounts we obtain a total expense of about 2,457,008.62.

Step 3. In addition, “Interest Receivables” in our data act as extra revenue items. When we add all the amounts from the interest receivable rows we get about 4,547.28.

Step 4. Finally the “Profit Before Tax” is computed by adding up the “Sales profit” and the “Interest” income and then subtracting total expenses. That is:

  Profit Before Tax = (Sales profit + Interest Receivable income) − Total Expenses  
    ≈ (1,744,991.36 + 4,547.28) − 2,457,008.62  
    ≈ 1,749,538.64 − 2,457,008.62  
    ≈ –707,469.98

Thus the final picture is that the business posts about –707,470 in pre‐tax profit (a loss) for the period.

We now present our answer in the requested JSON format.

-----------------------------------------

{
  "solution": {
    "Profit Before Tax": "-707469.98"
  }
}
